Title: Phylogenetic conservatism in plant phenology
TakeHome: Flowering and leafout times show phylogenetic signal because responses to cues are phylogenetically conserved
RelevancetoOurPaper: High - sets basis for our study
AddNotes: They measure phylogenetic signal in timings, not responses

Title: Meta-analysis of phenotypic selection on flowering phenology suggests that early flowering plants are favoured
TakeHome: Phylogenetic meta-analyses does not improve ordinary meta-analysis, but using phylogeny modifies the significance of predictors for flowering time
RelevancetoOurPaper: Mid-high - phylogenies may not matter in meta-analytic approaches
AddNotes: The authors do not directly test phylogenetic signal of phenology

Title: Conservatism and diversification of plant functional traits: Evolutionary rates versus phylogenetic signal
TakeHome: Evolutionary rate and phylogenetic signal may be unrelated
RelevancetoOurPaper: Low - perhaps to interpret final results
AddNotes: Should we plot traitgrams? So far we have not been thinking about diversificatioon at all.

Title: Time - size tradeoffs: a phylogenetic comparative study of flowering time, plant height and seed mass in a north-temperate flora
TakeHome: Correlations between flowering phenology and functional traits (seed size, height) differ between perennial herbs and woody plants
RelevancetoOurPaper: Low - but old study accounting for phylogeny-phenology

Title: Contraints and competition in the evolution of flowering phenology
TakeHome: Phylogenetic membership and life form strongly influence a species' flowering time
RelevancetoOurPaper: High - sets basis for our study
AddNotes: competition for pollination does not seem to push species' flowering times beyond seasonal boundaries

Title: Phylogenetic patterns of species loss in Thoreau's woods are driven by climate change
TakeHome: flowering-time response traits are shared among closely related species.
RelevancetoOurPaper: High - supports importance of phylogeny to phenology
AddNotes: They conclude that the effects of climate change on biodiversity would be phylogenetically biased

Title: Spring predictability explains different leaf?out strategies in the woody floras of North America, Europe and East Asia
TakeHome: species from regions with high STV have higher winter chilling requirements, and, leaf out later than related species from regions with lower STV
RelevancetoOurPaper: Low-mid - we do not have data to test procedence, but something to perhaps discuss

Title: On the importance of accounting for intraspecific genomic relatedness in multi-species studies
TakeHome: Methods paper showing how to include inter and intraspecific variation in ecological models with an example using the Flynn & Wolkovich data
RelevancetoOurPaper: Low-mid: Limited species (10) but did find 0.7 for signal and does suggest intraspecific variation matters, so worth mentioning I think.

Title: The phylogenetic mixed model
TakeHome: PMM is great and flexibl.
RelevancetoOurPaper: Methods

Title: Predicting�phenology�by integrating ecology, evolution and climate science
TakeHome: Overview in regards to phylogeny: Lays out how phylogeny might matter in terms of predicting missing species, projecting forward for adaptive potential. Also, nicely outlines this " Phylogenetic approaches can map both raw observational phenology data, such as flowering dates, as well as model estimates of how strongly species cue to different environmental variables such as temperature (Bolmgren & Cowan, 2008; Willis et al., 2008; Davis et al., 2010)." Not sure if the rates are great (given the quality of our data, but as J says 'it's easy to do, so, you know, why not?' and the community assembly stuff (which doesn't apply here as we don't have community data) requires 'being sensible to the current literature.'
RelevancetoOurPaper: Mid-high: See section starting on 3636 for a nice overview

Title: Phylogenetic analysis and comparative data: a test and review of evidence
RelevancetoOurPaper: Methods

Title: A global test for phylogenetic signal in shifts in flowering time under climate change
TakeHome: Signal in flowering shift (which is just a binned version of slope), but not slope so not sure on signal overall (trust molecular tree results; I recommend ignoring phylomatic results); OU models fit better (which is generally true of most traits)
RelevancetoOurPaper: Mid-cited a lot so worth mentioning, but does lots of dodgey things so be sure to read carefully (most of the results seem highly dependent on phylogeny so best not to trust much �) maybe we should have multiple trees?

phylogenetic signal stronger for FFD when conditions were less harsh (lower elevation). At higher elevation there might be less signal for phylo because of convergent evolution. high phenotypic plasticity in flowering times. How many spp 48
